Author: Luscinarius, Abdul
Full title: ΛΕΞΙΚΟΝ (Lexikon) seu dictionarium miraculorum, entium nec non phaenomenωn explicandorum, quae in Zamonia finibusque propinquis observantur. A–Z
Discipline/Content: Mathematics, Physics, Astronomy/Astrology/Cosmography, Geography/Cartography, Meteorology/Earth sciences, Alchemy/Chemistry, Biology, Medicine, Other (see description)
Original: ΛΕΞΙΚΟΝ (Lexikon) seu dictionarium miraculorum, entium nec non phaenomenωn explicandorum(Google Books)
Description: Abdul Luscinarius’s (Nachtigaller) comprehensive encyclopaedia contains short descriptions of marvels, life forms, and other phenomena of Zamonia and its environs in alphabetical order. The title page features a portrait of the author with the traditional academic caps on his four external brains. On the flyleaf Luscinarius’s scholarly mottoscientia nox(“knowledge is night”) can be read. The style contains elements of both colloquial and learned prose. The author does not simply relate facts but often adds judgmental side notes. Some of the entries recount hearsay information and there are notable shortcomings, e.g. in the case of the Common Spider Witch (Tarantula valkyria).The volume was published at Luscinarius’s own expense and disseminated by the students of his Nocturnal Academy. The famous poet Hildegunst von Mythenmetz frequently consulted the encyclopaedia but remained ambivalent about it as Luscinarius's positivist world view contradicted his own poetic view of things: however, due to its undisputed merits, the ΛΕΞΙΚΟΝ should not be ignored, not least because it invited Mythenmetz to contradict Luscinarius's writings (Mythenmetz 2002, 46). Apart from the unreliable testimonies of Ursus Caeruleus Nauta, Mythenmetz’s quotations are the main source of this otherwise lost work.
How to cite this entry: Luscinarius, Abdul:ΛΕΞΙΚΟΝ (Lexikon) seu dictionarium miraculorum, entium nec non phaenomenωn explicandorum, in: Noscemus Wiki, URL:http://wiki.uibk.ac.at/noscemus/ΛΕΞΙΚΟΝ_(Lexikon)_seu_dictionarium_miraculorum,_entium_nec_non_phaenomenωn_explicandorum(last revision: 29.10.2022).

Author: Borrhaus, Martin
Full title: ΜΑΘΗΜΑΤΩΝ ΣΤΟΙΧΕΙΑ. Hoc est elementale cosmographicum, quo totius et Astronomiae et Geographiae rudimenta certissimis brevissimisque docentur apodixibus
Description: Borrhaus' work is a short compendium on cosmography and geography on 75 pages. It is accompanied by a letter to the printer, Crato Mylius (Kraft Müller), by the author and a dedicatory letter by Achilles Pirmin Gasser, who arranged the publication, to the physician and natural philosopher Petrus Rhotus. Gasser explains that the text was designed as a compilation or short handbook for students in Wittenberg. The work itself is divided into two parts, a considerably longer part on astronomy and a shorter part (ca. 20 pages) on geography. In both parts, several chapters collect the most important knowledge, stating one short item of information after the other in a list, which is numbered in marginalia. While the first edition contains only text, a further edition printed under the Latin title in Paris in 1551 contains useful images and annotations (cf. the digital copy.)
How to cite this entry: Borrhaus, Martin:ΜΑΘΗΜΑΤΩΝ ΣΤΟΙΧΕΙΑ (Mathematon stoicheia), in: Noscemus Wiki, URL:http://wiki.uibk.ac.at/noscemus/ΜΑΘΗΜΑΤΩΝ_ΣΤΟΙΧΕΙΑ_(Mathematon_stoicheia)(last revision: 14.09.2022).

Author: De Rycke, Josse
Full title: Urbano VIII pontifici optimo maximo, cum accuratior ΜΕΛΙΣΣΟΓΡΑΦΙΑ a Lynceorum academia in perpetuae devotionis symbolum ipsi offerretur
Description: TheAccademia dei Lincei(“Academy of the Lynx-Eyed”), founded by Federico Cesi in 1603, was the first academy devoted to the natural sciences, their emblem and name giver being the lynx, an animal famous for its sharp-sightedness. The most renowned member of this Roman Academy wasGalileo Galilei, who fundamentally changed the perception of the universe through his astronomicalobservations with the telescope. However, the sharp-eyedLinceiwere pioneers in observing nature with the microscope, too: In 1625, they made the “first printed illustration in the history of natural history to have been made with the aid of a microscope” (Freedberg 2002, 161). This illustration, an impressive large-format engraving on a single sheet (41,6 x 30,7 cm) made by Matthias Greuter, is carefully crafted to promote the first microscopic observations by theLincei– as well as the academy in general – to Maffeo Barberini,pope Urban VIII.As a piece of promotion of science, the engraving consists of an interesting cross-over of heraldic and scientific representation: it presents the pope with the three Barberini bees of his coat of arms, but they are depicted according to how they look under the microscope. Each of the three bees offers a different view (topside, underside, side-view), with further depictions of anatomic details of the bee engraved on a band of parchment at the bottom of the page. These microscopic details surround a Latin panegyric poem in the centre of the parchment (the bee's leg even forms an attractive ornamental line below the text). Like the microscopic observation of the bee, which were done by Francesco Stelluti, the poem is also the work of a member of theAccademia dei Lincei, the Flemish philologist and poet Josse de Rycke.The poem consists of eight elegiac couplets, praising microscopy through the lense of the Barberini bee: the pope is invited to look at his heraldic animal as it has been observed and depicted by theLincei. In v. 11-13, the poem seems to morph into a microscope itself, describing four new details of the bee's anatomy that have been discovered by microscopic observation, like their lion-like mane. The new art of microscopy is advertised as revealing the greatest miracles (v. 9) and divine discoveries (v. 14), and the sacred work of theLincei(v. 7) especially is presented as inspired by the genius of the Cesi and assisted by Pallas’s art (i.e. the microscope). The engraving, together with the epigram, is an impressive testament to the potential of theLincei’s sharp-sighted observations, which is exemplified in the promotion of the Barberini bee of pope Urban VIII on the occasion of the Jubilee year of 1625.The engraving – connected to Federico Cesi’sApiariumon the anatomy of bees, which was printed one year later – survives only in a few copies. As this very target-specific form of promotion already suggests, the sheet seems to have been presented only to a select number of addressees: the primary addressee is, of course, Pope Urban VIII, but copies of the MΕΛΙΣΣΟΓΡΑΦΙΑ were also presented as diplomatic gifts to Archduke Leopold of Austria and Landgrave Louis V of Darmstadt (cf.Brevaglieri 2015, 146–9).
Cited in: De Rycke, Josse‎(← links)Apiarium‎(← links)Microscopium‎(← links)
How to cite this entry: De Rycke, Josse:ΜΕΛΙΣΣΟΓΡΑΦΙΑ (Melissographia), in: Noscemus Wiki, URL:http://wiki.uibk.ac.at/noscemus/ΜΕΛΙΣΣΟΓΡΑΦΙΑ_(Melissographia)(last revision: 22.02.2022).
Internal notes: According to secondary literature, this engraving seems to feature the first public mention of the term "microscope".

Author: Scheuchzer, Johann Jakob
Full title: ΟΥΡΕΣΙΦΟΙΤΗΣ Helveticus sive itinera per Helvetiae Alpinas regiones facta annis MDCCII, MDCCIII, MDCCIV, MDCCV, MDCCVI, MDCCVII, MDCCIX, MDCCX, MDCCXI. Plurimis tabulis aeneis illustrata a Johanne Jacobo Scheuchzero Tigurino, medicinae doctore, mathematicae professore, Academiae Leopoldino-Carolinae et Societatum Regiarum Anglicae ac Prussicae membro. In quattuor tomos distincta.
Discipline/Content: Geography/Cartography, Meteorology/Earth sciences, Biology, Medicine, Other (see description)
Description: Published in its definitive form in four substantial volumes in 1723 after a preliminary partial edition in 1708, this is an opus magnum by one of the foremost Swiss naturalists of the 18th century. In the form of a scientific diary, Scheuchzer describes nine journeys that led him through many parts of the eastern Swiss Alps in the summers of the years 1702–1707 and 1709–1711. The work, whose publication was financed by its dedicatee, the Royal Society, and which is lavishly illustrated, touches upon many scientific disciplines, the most important of which are geography, geology and earth history, meteorology (Scheuchzer regularly determines the altitude of certain places with the help of a barometer), botany, zoology (including dragons) and medicine (including balneology). Apart from its scientific contents, the book is also noteworthy because of the way in which science is presented as a heroic activity and an intense personal experience, and because of its vivid, graphic, sometimes lofty style. As an appendix, Scheuchzer publishes his auto-bibliography, theAcarnania.
Cited in: Scheuchzer, Johann Jakob‎(← links)Recensio Itineris Alpini Ioannis Iacobi Scheuchzeri‎(← links)Acarnania‎(← links)
How to cite this entry: Scheuchzer, Johann Jakob:ΟΥΡΕΣΙΦΟΙΤΗΣ (Ouresiphoites) Helveticus, in: Noscemus Wiki, URL:http://wiki.uibk.ac.at/noscemus/ΟΥΡΕΣΙΦΟΙΤΗΣ_(Ouresiphoites)_Helveticus(last revision: 27.07.2021).
Internal notes:
Tomus primus (= Itinera 1702, 1703, 1704)Praefatio ad lectorem: Erforschung der Heimat mindestens ebenso verdienstvoll wie ferner Länder. Weg führt ad ipsa eaque celsissima Alpium juga. Vielfältige Merkwürdigkeiten aus den unterschiedlichsten Gebieten (nicht etwa nur geologische). Publikation aufgrund internationalen Interesses.
Vorrede des Herausgebers: Buch enthält Karte, viele schöne Stiche, tot et tanta Naturae miranda, dass es nicht seinesgleichen hat. Autopsie. [Wissenschaft und persönl. Erleben kombiniert – ein besonderer Reiz.]
3f. beginnt mit langem Zitat aus Gesner, Epistola de mont. adm., dem er nacheifern will. Musen als Berggottheiten. Beweggrund u.a.: proprio … et innato veluti instinctu motus.
4 Verbindung von Wissenschaft, Poesie und Gebirge: … ego, alumnus Musarum, quae amant bicipitem Parnassum, Heliconis amoenitates, Aonumque et Pieriae cacumina …
6f. Besteigt Klein Aubrig.
Stich zw. S. 6/7: Sumptibus D. Isaac Newton...
8f. et multotiens: Höhenmessung mittels Barometer. Häufig auf Berggipfeln, die anscheinend zu diesem Zweck bestiegen werden.
21 Beschreibung und Höhenmessung des Titlis, Nennung vieler anderer Berge.
23 Wasserfälle als genussvoller Anblick: … maxime recreat visum spumosa sua et lactea veluti albedine der Deusbach …
26 seltsame Gemsen
28 Besteigung des Pilatus, spicilegium von Beobachtungen nach Gessner (nichts zur Aussicht). Höhe wird mit Barometer auf ca. 840m ab Luzern geschätzt, also wie auch die anderer Berge unterschätzt.
29–52 Index der auf der ersten Reise gesammelten Pflanzen. So auch im Folgenden nach jeder Reise.
52–62 Traktat über die Milch etc., realistischere Ergänzung zu Gesners gelehrt-philologischem Opus, mit vielen Stichen.
65f. Vorrede zum zweiten Iter: Extimulat me proprium meum Naturam noscendi desiderium, quo magis magisque flagro … Wissenschaftsheroismus. Sic gratiam, qua destituuntur reculae meae, compensabut Laboris difficultas et Veritatis studium adorandae in nivosis Alpium iugis, ubi veluti in throno regio multis hactenus inaccesso sedet, corona cincta saxea, mento lanugine cano, crinibus autem et amictu vestita viridibus. (nach Tasso, der dann zitiert wird).
71f. Güte des Schweizer Bergwassers, belegt mit Zitaten aus ???? ?????.
73f. Methodik des Gebrauchs des Barometers als Messinstrument
80 wie 23 Wasserfall als iucundum … spectaculum.
80f. Bergkatalog, wie öfters.
82 aeris Alpini puritas.
86 Calanda von einer Seite praerupta valde et altis praecipitiis horrida. Verweist zu dem Berg auf die Literatur (Fabricius, Gesner, Aretius), die er alle kennt.
87 … perambulavimus pedibus Vallem Vettensem pratis peramoenis fontibusque limpidissimis plenam.
88 Die Alpen als Wolkengeneratoren für ganz Europa? Falls ja, Zeichen für summam Creatoris sapientiam und utilitas, immo necessitas der Alpen.
91f. Ein General betrachtet den Heintzenberg summa cum delectatione …, quod … numquam viderit Montem cultiorem simul et amoeniorem.
95 (zur Via Mala) angustiae nonnullae satis horridae, so auch sonst noch oft.
102 celeberrimae et numerosissimae Cryptae Aeoliae bei Clavenna
105 zitiert Franciscus Nigers Rhetia (lat. Hex.)
107 Catadupa, qua pulchriorem hactenus non vidi … alle Unannehmlichkeiten discutit tum Catadupae ipsius, tum Iridis circularis et pulcherrimae aspectus …
110 lubuit hac die pedum nostrorum vires porro experiri: Conscendimus igitur ramum praealtum Septimi Montis …
153 wilde Schlucht: saxorum imminentium et sese desuper claudentium … altum horridumque aspectum … iucundam admirationem insuper praebent saxorum undulatae et passim complanatae superficies … terrorem denique incutit Taminnae … aspectus …
157–9 spannende und gefährliche Gamsjagd (wozu es offenbar schon eine weitläufige Literatur gibt)Tomus secundus (= Iter 1705)
169f. reist meist in Begleitung; Adressat wie auch sonst immer die Royal Academy.
Vor 179 Karte von Glarus
189–191 Die Berge schrecklich und unnütz? Nein, im Gegenteil, machen als Wasserreservoir Land und alles fruchtbar. Die Täler zwischen ihnen sind herrlich windgeschützt. Vergleich mit englischen Gärten und Anrede an die Akademiemitglieder. Gott sei gepriesen!
203 Zerstäubender Wasserfall cum voluptate videre est.
211 Aufstieg zum Gotthard: Via iucunda simul est et horrida aufgrund der vielfältigen im Folgenden aufgezählten Eindrücke. WIEDER GENUSS WIDERSTREITENDER EMOTIONEN.
214 Bleiben wir ein bisschen auf dem Gotthard, editissima Europae specula, und handeln ein paar Themen ab, z.B. Lawinen und Kristalle (was dann bis S. 258  in extenso geschieht; doch auch S. 260 sitzt man noch auf dem Gotthard)
220-33 ausführliche Lawinenkunde: Wortkunde, Wächten/Schneeverwehungen, Labinarum genera mit älterer Literatur (Rebmann, Silius, Claudian), Causae efficientes, Praeservatio, Behandlung von Lawinenopfern, Lawinen können Überschwemmungen verursachen, Lawinenschnee bleibt im Tal lange liegen, Lawinenopfer verfaulen im Schnee nicht, Lawinenchronik (nicht chronologisch) mit einem dt. carmen lugubre.
252 Die helvetischen Alpen, keine anderen, constituunt Europae Iuga.
281 Gletscher als Phänomen, quod nos media etiam aestate summa cum delectatione intuemur quotidie. 
282 Ständig schneebedeckte Berge finden manche schlimm. Nos contra Summi Conditoris erga nos optimam Clementiam adoramus et plenis buccis depraedicamus numerantes nivosa montium nostrorum cacumena in primis felicitatis Helveticae bonis. 
288 Ein pictor topiarius (Landschaftsmaler), der Gletscher besucht, ut ad vivos eos delinearet.
315f. Gefährlicher, wilder Übergang über den Gemmipass (< gemitus) mit eindrücklichem Stich.Tomus tertius (Itinera 1706, 1707, 1709)
S. 353f. (praefatio zum fünften iter: Montosa haec est regio, si quae, et curiositatibus equidem referta, sed talibus, quae non comparantur parvi, sudoribus constant, laboribus, impensis, periculis... Ast praevalet adhuc semper curiosum Helvetiae magis et magis perquirendae desiderium...)
S. 359 Kurzbeschreibung des Pilatus; Luzern ist amoenissimi ad Lacum eiusdem nominis et Montis Pilati radicem situs.
S. 397–400 (Aufstieg auf den Pilatus, der damals schon öfter bestiegen wurde –  zwei gebräuchliche Wege aus dem Eigental werden genannt; barometrische Höhenmessungen, wie auch sonst immer; 399 Aussicht, ohne ästhetische Markierung)
S. 403f. (Passübergang von Engelberg aus, Blick auf Titlis etc.)
S. 429f. (praefatio zum sechsten iter: voluptas und dolor nach Sokrates miteinander verbunden, viele Mühen, aber tacito quodam stimulo ductus et tractus gibt er nicht auf; es helfen Applaus ausländischer Gelehrter und patriae inserviendi, et proprium, quo accensus feror, labores hosce continuandi, et ad DEI Creatoris Gloriam quidem, desiderium.
S. 430f. (Fahrt übern Walensee: recreabimus mentes et pascemus simul oculos – folgt enthusiastische, erkenntnisbegeisterte Beschreibung des Gebirgspanoramas um den See und der geologischen Einblicke, die es ermöglicht: oculis hic exposita sunt, quae in aliis Europae Regionibus quaeri debent in abditis visceribus...; Berge bei der Sintflut entstanden)
S. 431–3 (die Berge als Beispiel für Gottes Architektur – Ecce enim Architecturae Divinae alique saltem vestigia ... ausführliche Beschreibung in architekt. Termini. Aber, wird man einwenden, das ist ja alles chaotisch und hässlich (mit Zitat)! Aber umso toller, novus exoritur ordo in summa confusione regularissimus...)
S. 435f. (an einer senkrechten, gut 200m hohen Felswand wird cum discrimine vitae eine Höhenmessung durchgeführt, um Höhenmessungen per Barometer auf ihre Genauigkeit zu prüfen)
440 Beschreibung einer Besteigung des Piz Beverin bei Schams und der Aussicht (prospectus) vom Gipfel
S. 467f. (praefatio zum siebten iter: u.a. autopsia, tot itinera per montium altissima iuga)
S. 468 Beschreibung eines schönen prospectus vom Zürichsee Richtung Schwyzer, Glarner und Rätische Alpen.
S. 482f. (wollen Gletscher von Grindelwald besuchen tota fere Helvetia celeberrimos; unsicheres Wetter, sed vicit omnemque timorem discussit rarum naturae spectaculum ... videndi cupido; Beschreibung des Gletschers, Genaueres s. Iter des Jahres 1705)
S. 484f. Überschreitung des GemmipassesTomus quartus (Itinera 1710, 1711, Acarnania)
S. 523f. (praefatio zum achten iter; ähnlich wie die vorigen praefationes; Ziel der excursio Alpina ist vertiefte Gotteserkenntnis)
532f. Besteigung des Freibergs in Glarus, um im Tierschutzgebiet Gemsenherden zu sehen und Barometer-Experimente anzustellen. Einer der Begleiter, ein eingefleischter Gamsjäger, stürzt einige Jahre danach tödlich ab.
551ff. mit eigener Überschrift Toggici comitatus descriptio.
605 ligna fossilia im Kandertal. Während der Sintflut ab aquis diluvialibus madefacta und vom Gewicht der Ablagerungen darüber flachgepresst. Ähnlich andernorts Mischeln, Schnecken, Fische
Der Iter octavus hat keine Pflanzenliste, der neunte keine praefatio.Acarnania
Itinera Alpina enden S. 606, danach kommt ab S. 609 Acarnania sive relatio eorum quae hactenus elaboravit Acarnan, Joh. Jacobus Scheuchzer usw. Es handelt sich um eine von Scheuchzer selbst erstellte bibliografia ragionata.
609 Andere Ärzte streben nach Gewinn, Sch. ist von Natur aus eine Entdeckerpersönlichkeit. Ego nescio quo fato a tenera iuventue terras quaesivi vel incognitas vel parum tritas, nova sulcavi maria vel parum frequentata, labores amavi, observationes, nullis parcendo sumtibus.S. generell für interessante Dinge den ausführlichen Index.Es existieren ältere Ausgaben, dies ist die definitive und vollständige. Das Exemplar im Sharebereich hat viele Bilder nicht. Perfekt (bis auf ganz wenige fehlende Bilder) ist das Online-Exemplar.

Author: Bauhin, Caspar
Full title: ΠΙΝΑΞ (Pinax) theatri botanici Caspari Bauhini Basileensis archiatri et professoris ordinarii sive Index in Theophrasti, Dioscoridis, Plinii et botanicorum qui a saeculo scripserunt opera. Plantarum circiter sex millium ab ipsis exhibitarum nomina cum earundem synonymiis et differentiis methodice secundum earum et genera et species proponens. Opus XL annorum hactenus non editum, summopere expetitum et ad auctores intelligendos plurimum faciens. Galenus I. de Antid. V. Medicus omnium stirpium, si fieri potest, peritiam habeat consulo; sin minus, plurimarum saltem, quibus frequenter utimur
Original: Pinax theatri botanici(e-rara.ch)Alternative link:Biblioteca Digital Real Jardín Botánico
Description: Bauhin'sTable of the Theatre of Botany, a revised and greatly enlarged version of his earlierΦΥΤΟΠΙΝΑΞ(Phytopinax, 1596), is not, as one might suspect, a comprehensiveHistoria plantarumin the usual sense of the word. The plants contained in it are as a rule not described but only adduced with the name given them by Bauhin and a list of synonyms from ancient, medieval and early modern authors. Thus, the work may be called an encyclopedic dictionary of synonyms. It aims at ordering the Babylonian confusion of tongues that reigned in early modern botany.In twelve books (a number that carries associations of perfection and exhaustiveness) and on c. 600 pages printed in small font and in two columns, the work lists some 6000 different plants. The first ten books deal with herbs, while books 11 and 12 are dedicated to shrubs and trees. Overall, Bauhin applies an Aristotelian order, as he starts from the 'simplest' plants, that is, plants without seeds, and then proceeds to more 'developed' ones. The books are divided into sections, each of which is devoted to one or several groups of plants sharing a number of morphological features. Most interestingly in the light of later developments, these groups, which are given a common name (e.g.Sparganium, p. 15), are subdivided further into smaller unities with the help of one or several adjectives (Sparganium ramosum,Sparganium non ramosum,Sparganium minimum). Thus, Bauhin appears as a precursor of the Linnean system, in which genera are subdivided into species in the very same way (the rook, for example, which belongs to the genusCorvus, is characterized by the addition of the adjectivefrugilegus) (cf.Meier Reeds 1991, 132).As befits an opus magnum like this on which a leading botanist has spent forty years of his life (as the title proudly announces), the book features a rich paratextual apparatus: a dedication to Adam Zorn of Strasbourg, apraefatioto the reader, six epigrams by friends of Bauhin, a list of the works used and cited, and a list of persons who have sent specimens of plants and seeds to Bauhin. Most importantly in terms of usability, the work concludes with an exhaustive index of plant names.
How to cite this entry: Bauhin, Caspar:ΠΙΝΑΞ (Pinax) theatri botanici, in: Noscemus Wiki, URL:http://wiki.uibk.ac.at/noscemus/ΠΙΝΑΞ_(Pinax)_theatri_botanici(last revision: 20.02.2022).

Author: Colonna, Fabio
Full title: ΦΥΤΟΒΑΣΑΝΟΣ (Phytobasanos) sive plantarum aliquot historia, in qua describuntur diversi generis plantae veriores ac magis facie viribusque respondentes antiquorum Theophrasti, Dioscoridis, Plinii, Galeni aliorumque delineationibus, ab aliis hucusque non animadversae. Fabio Columna authore. Accessit etiam piscium aliquot plantarumque novarum historia eodem authore
Description:
The Greek title of this botanical work by a member of the Accademia dei Lincei means literally “touchstone” or “trial of plants”. In the dedicatory letter to Cardinal Marco Antonio Colonna, the author makes clear that this is his first work (Excipe igitur, obsecro, ingenii mei primitias). In the following letter to the reader, Fabio Colonna, praises the study of plants asmateria medicaand explains the origin of this work. The author himself suffered from epilepsy and other illnesses. Therefore, he studied ancient medical texts by Hippocrates, Galen, and others to check if their treatments could corroborate the prescriptions of his own doctors. Then, there is a poem by a certain Franciscus Maurus Maidensis in elegiac couplets addressing the reader and praising Colonna’s work.The work on plants comprises 120 pages of which several pages are devoted to each plant. Colonna discusses that names and their etymology, the outward appearance, blooming period, habitat, and medical properties. The work is probably the first to feature an engraving of each plant discussed that allows for more details than a woodcut. Colonna’s main source text is Dioscorides’ workmateria medicafrom which he frequently cites. Longer Greek passages are also translated. Colonna then discusses these ancient descriptions and compares them to other texts (both ancient and early modern), and also to his own observations. Hence, Colonna proposes quite a few corrections. References to Colonna’s sources are printed in the margins. 
The work on plants is followed by an appendix of four kinds of ‘fish’, or rather any aquatic animals (Rhinobatos, a kind of ray, a kind of sea star, barnacles), and of eight plant species with new pagination (32 pages) and another short letter to the reader. In this letter, Colonna explains that he did not want to disturb the order of his book on plants with the new information on plants that he has gathered during the editing and printing process and therefore adds them in the end. He also proposes to include further information in either a planned commentary on Dioscorides or – if this is not going to happen – in another edition of the present work.
The first entry of the part on ‘fish’ is on theRhinobatos(guitarfish) to which Franciscus Maurus contributed another poem in four elegiac couplets, but this time in Greek. There is also another Greek epigram at the end dedicated to Colonna by a Jesuit named Francisco Guerrieri (Οὐερριήριος). Finally, there is a short list of amendments, an alphabetic index, and a list of errata.
How to cite this entry: Colonna, Fabio:ΦΥΤΟΒΑΣΑΝΟΣ (Phytobasanos), in: Noscemus Wiki, URL:http://wiki.uibk.ac.at/noscemus/ΦΥΤΟΒΑΣΑΝΟΣ_(Phytobasanos)(last revision: 16.08.2021).

Author: Scultetus, Johannes
Full title: ΧΕΙΡΟΠΛΟΘΗΚΗ seu domini Ioannis Sculteti, physici et chirurgi apud Ulmenses olim felicissimi, armamentarium chirurgicum XLIII tabulis aeri elegantissime incisis nec antehac visis exornatum. Opus posthumum, medicinae pariter ac chirurgiae studiosis perutile et necessarium, in quo tot tam veterum ac recentiorum instrumenta ab auctore correcta quam noviter ab ipso inventa, quot fere hodie ad usitatas operationes manuales feliciter peragendas requiruntur, iusta et hactenus semper desiderata magnitudine et applicandi modo depicta reperiuntur, cum annexa brevi tabularum descriptione et sequentibus cautionibus ac curationibus chirurgico-medicis per omnes fere corporis humani partes externas observatis. Nunc primum in lucem editum studio et opera Joannis Sculteti, authoris ex fratre nepotis, philosophiae et medicinae doctoris. Cum triplici instrumentorum, curationum rerumque memorabilium indice.
Description: On 43 high-quality copper tables, the first part (pp. 1–67) of this work gives an overview of the most important chirurgical instruments and operation techniques of its time, including some inventions by the author himself. Each instrument or procedure is assigned a Roman number, to which the author refers in his detailed and precise commentaries on the single tables. The second part (pp. 68–131) consists of one hundred detailed, graphic, and self-promotional case histories (observationes) of patients treated by the author that exemplify and illustrate the general descriptions of part one. The whole is intended to teach not only the use but also the fabrication of the respective instruments. The work is preceded by a dedicatory epistle to the consuls of Ulm (written by the author's nephew, the posthumous editor of the work), a preface to the reader, nine short laudatory poems by other physicians from Ulm, and anIndex instrumentorum. At the end follow anIndex observationum, anIndex rerumandErrata graviora.TheArmamentarium chirurgicumwas hugely successful. It was reprinted several times and also appeared in Dutch, French, and German translations.
How to cite this entry: Scultetus, Johannes:ΧΕΙΡΟΠΛΟΘΗΚΗ (Cheiroplotheke), in: Noscemus Wiki, URL:http://wiki.uibk.ac.at/noscemus/ΧΕΙΡΟΠΛΟΘΗΚΗ_(Cheiroplotheke)(last revision: 14.02.2022).
Internal notes: Indications regarding the size of the instruments in comparison to their depictions are often given.The rich terminology and the graphic descriptions of the instruments are of great interest.

Author: Brunfels, Otto
Full title: Ὀνομαστικόν [Onomastikon] medicinae continens omnia nomina herbarum, fructicum, suffruticum, arborum, sentium, seminum, florum, radicum, lapidum preciosorum, metallorum, colorum, definitionum medicinalium, instrumentarum medicinae, unguentorum, diapasmatum, emplastorum, eclegmatum, acoporum, suffituum, electariorum, pharmacorum, clysterium, balanorum, pessorum, pastillorum, malagmatum, balnearum, chirurgiae, morborum pecudum, animantium omnis generis, nomina propria eorum, quae in myropoliis habentur, morborum, medicorum et inventorum medicinae, anatomiae, ponderum, philosophiae naturalis, magiae, a<l>chimiae et astrologiae. Ex optimis, probatissimis et vetustissimis autoribus cum Graecis, tum Latinis, opus recens nuper multa lectione Othonis Brunfelsii, medicinae professoris, congestum in gratiam eorum, qui se priscae medicinae dediderunt. Praescriptis operi tabulis nominum anatomiae et aegritudinum totius corporis humani. Saladini item iudicio de ponderibus medicinalibus.
Description: In his letter to the reader, Otto Brunfels states that there might be no more annoying literary work than to write dictionaries:Inter tam multa scribendi argumenta et genera … haud scio, an ullum molestius extet quam lexicorum commentarios scribere.. He highlights the difficulties of this task, such as to find good sources, to have a sound knowledge on the topic, and to find the right balance. Such work is, however, very important as the language must be “cleaned” from exotic (i.e., Arabic) and vulgar terms and he encourages experts of other disciplines to undertake this task as well. It should serve the education of young men. Moreover, Brunfels highlights thatLeonhart Fuchsis preparing a new edition of thePandectae medicinae, which he eagerly awaits.Apart from this letter to the reader, there are a few other paratexts. There is a table of anatomical terms (Tabula nominum anatomiae) listing Greek terms together with their Latin translation ordereda capite ad calcem. This is followed by a similarly structured catalogue of diseases (Cathalogus omnium aegritudinum, quae fere accidunt homini a capite usque ad pedes, quorum interpretationem require in Lexico sequenti); this time without translations as these can be found in the lexicon. Moreover, there is an overview of measurements by Saladin and a list of quotations of Galen (translated into Latin), in which he seems to state that people should rather concentrate on the facts and not quarrel about names.The lexicon itself is ordered alphabetically and offers Latin and Greek lemmata together with a short explanation and links to references (mostly of ancient texts). As already indicated in the title, it consists of a very broad spectrum of medical terms comprisinginter aliaanatomy, diseases, differentmateria medica, medical instruments, cures, etc.The work was reprinted in Strasbourg twice, in 1543 and 1553 (Tonelli 1971, 11).
How to cite this entry: Brunfels, Otto:Ὀνομαστικόν medicinae, in: Noscemus Wiki, URL:http://wiki.uibk.ac.at/noscemus/Ὀνομαστικόν_medicinae(last revision: 10.01.2022).
